info.title: Git Essentials
info.description: Git is a distributed version control system which helps to track a product history over time and to collaborate easily with others. This KEEMI catalog is aimed at developers which use Git in their daily work want to have the essentials in mind.

question.name: glossaryWorkingTree
question.text: Look at the options below. Which options matches the meaning of a working tree?

answerItem.text: a set of files and directories currently being worked on
you can work in your working tree without using git at all
the working tree is normally equal to the HEAD plus any local changes that you have made but not yet committed
the working tree has your checked out files / source code
contains a special top-level directory named ".git"
any git command must be executed within the working tree or its subdirectories
the working tree contains all the history of your project
the working tree is also called staging area or index
you add files with: git add nameOfFile to the working tree

question.name: glossaryStagingArea
question.text: You want to add a modified tracked file: file1.txt to the staging area. How can you do that with the command: add?

question.name: glossaryRepositoryObjDbTypes
question.text: Which types of objects can be stored in the object database of a Git repository?

answerItem.text: Blob - the content of a file
Tree - references Blob's and other Tree's
Commit - contains e.g. the name of the author and commit date, references a Tree and other Commit's
Tag - contains the name of a Tag, references a Commit / Commit Object

question.name: glossaryCommitObject
question.text: Which informations are stored within a commit object?

answerItem.text: the tree object which corresponds to the top directory of the stored commit

question.name: glossaryCommit
question.text: What is the command sequence to commit changes, made in a file: file1.txt, into the repository?

question.name: glossaryHead
question.text: Look at the options below. Which options matches the meaning of HEAD?

answerItem.text: The HEAD is a reference to the most recent commit on the current branch
Heads are stored in a file in $GIT_DIR/refs/heads/ directory, except when using packed refs.
It is possible for HEAD to refer to a specific commit that is not associated with a branch name. This situation is called a detached HEAD
Is the parent of the next commit
The tracked files referred by HEAD define what goes in to the next commit
The files referred by HEAD and the files in the working tree are always the same
The files referred by HEAD and the files in the staging area are always the same

question.name: logOutput
question.title: git log
question.text: Select all options which are printed by the command: git log

answerItem.text: a diff of the made changes

question.name: configNameAndEmail
question.text: You want to configure the user name and e-mail for a specific repository. Finally you want to check the configuration of the repository. Which commands you use?

question.name: commitAll
question.title: git commit -a
question.text: What is the result of the command: git commit -a ?

answerItem.text: all files, changed in the working tree, are staged automatically and committed into the repository
all files, added and changed in the working tree, are staged automatically and committed into the repository
all files, changed in the staging are, are committed without a commit message
all files in the staging area are attached to the last commit made

question.name: diffFileStagingAreaAndRepo

section.text: You add a new file with the name: file1.txt to the working tree and write the line: line1 at the beginning of the file content. After that you execute the following git commands:
git add fil1.txt
git commit -m "added a new file"
Than you change the first line of the file1.txt from: line1 to line0 and execute the following git command:
git add -u

question.name: discardAllLocalChangesFromFile1

section.text: Starting point is a clean working tree!
You add a new file with the name: file1.txt to the working tree and writes the line: line1 at the beginning of the file content. After that you commit the new added file to the repository using:
git add fil1.txt
git commit -m "added file1.txt"
Than you change the content of the file: file1.txt from line1 to line0 and push the modified file to the staging area with:
git add -u
At last you change the content again from line0 to lineN.

question.title: Read the introduction and answer the question
question.text: Which command can be used to discard the last made change?

question.text: What is the content of the file: file1.txt now?

question.text: You want to discard all made modifications from file1.txt and update the content to the one stored in the last commit. Which commands you use?

question.name: nothingToCommit
question.title: Nothing to Commit
question.text: If git status says "Nothing to commit", what’s in the staging area?

answerItem.text: working tree and staging area are synchronized with HEAD, the staging area is not empty and contains the same files as in the working tree
working tree and staging area contain different files, the files in the staging area are all committed into the repository
the working tree contains changed files which are not added to the staging area yet
the staging area contains no files

question.name: improvingCommit
question.text: You forgot to add a file: file2.txt to the last commit. Which command can you use to amend the last commit?

question.name: revertADeletedModifiedFile

section.text: Starting point is a clean working tree!
You make some modifications to the content of a tracked file: file1.txt. Than you accidentally remove file1.txt using the command:
git rm file1.txt

question.title: Read the introduction and answer the question
question.text: Can you restore the file with the modifications you made?

question.name: restoringADeletedFile
question.text: You deleted a file: file1.txt in a previous commit. Now you want to restore the deleted file: file1.txt. What can you do?

answerItem.text: You have to find the commit that deleted the file. You can do that with the command: git log --diff-filter=D --summary This command shows you all commits which comprise deletions of files.

If you found the commit which deletes the file, take the commit-ID and use the following command: git checkout c20072c6^ -- file1.txt This command restores the file: file1.txt from the commit before the one with the short ID:c20072c6

question.name: visualDiffTrackedFile

section.text: Starting point is a clean working tree!
A tracked file: file1.txt has the following content.
You change the content by deleting the text with number 1 and 3. Than you push the updated file to the staging area with:
git add file1.txt
After that you want to restore the text numbered with 3 using vimdiff considering the procedure shown at the pictures below.

question.title: Read the introduction and order the commands properly
question.text: Restore the text numbered 3 using vimdiff ( consider the pictures from the introduction )!

question.name: createNewBranch
question.text: What happens if you create a branch named syncFeature with: git branch syncFeature ?

answerItem.text: A new reference is created, the reference is stored as file .git/refs/heads/syncFeature , the content of the file is the commit-ID the HEAD reference points to.
A new commit object is created, the object stores the name of the branch and all modified files from the staging area.
All files referred by the branch named syncFeature are stored into the staging area and working tree. If the staging area or working tree contain modified files, the operation is canceled.
All files referred by the branch named syncFeature are stored into working tree. If the working tree contains modified files, the operation is canceled.

question.text: Which command sequence built the commit graph? Setup the repositories at first, starting with the remote!

answerItem.text: git commit -m "First version of the KEEMI documentation."
git commit -m "Added .gitignore to ignore the Desktop Services Store(.DS_Store) under Mac OS"

section.text: The Git working tree can be described by the following items:

section.title: A clean working tree
section.text: A working tree is clean, if it corresponds to the revision referenced by the current HEAD.

explanation.name: glossaryStagingArea
explanation.title: Staging Area
explanation.section: The staging area is a collection of files with status information, whose contents are stored as objects. It is a stored version of your working tree and is a simple file, generally contained in your .git directory.The information within the staging area defines what goes into your next commit.The staging area is sometimes referred to as the index, but it’s becoming standard to refer to it as the staging area.To add new or changed files to the staging area use the command: add as follows: can be used.The option -u adds all changed files to the staging area, option -A all changed and new added ones.

section.title: Tracked files
section.text: Once a file is added to the staging area, the file path is known to git and is considered as tracked.

The purpose of Git is to manage a project, or a set of files, as they change over time. Git stores this information in a data structure called a repository. A git repository contains, among other things, the following:
A set of commit objects
A set of references to commit objects

The Git repository is stored in the same directory as the project itself, in a subdirectory called .git. There is only one .git directory, in the root directory of the project. The repository is stored in files alongside the project. There is no central server repository.

section.title: The Object Database
section.text: Git stores commit objects into an object database. Next to commit objects Git handles the following types of objects

Every stored object is uniquely identified by an ID. The ID is a HASH value generated by the Secure Hash Algorithm 1 and usually represented by the 40 character hexadecimal encoding ( e.g. 2be2c6dbf31582b84d0fa92d88d487c8b9700c28 ).
A commit object contains the information about a particular commit, such as:
The commit-ID is the unique identifier of the stored commit object.
A parent is a commit object containing a (possibly empty) list of the logical predecessor(s) in the line of development, i.e. its parents.
The author date notes when this commit was originally made (i.e. when you finished the git commit). According to the docs of git commit, the author date could be overridden using the --date switch.
The commit date gets changed every time the commit is being modified, for example when rebasing the branch where the commit is in on another branch.

As a noun: A single point in the git history; the entire history of a project is represented as a set of interrelated commits. The word "commit" is often used by git in the same places other revision control systems use the words "revision" or "version". Also used as a short hand for commit object.

As a verb: The action of storing a new snapshot of the project’s state in the git history, by creating a new commit representing the current state of the index and advancing HEAD to point at the new commit.
To commit changes made at a file: file1.txt in the working tree, the following commands can be executed:

You can think of the HEAD as the "current branch". When you switch branches with git checkout, the HEAD reference changes to point to the tip of the new branch. It is possible for HEAD to refer to a specific revision that is not associated with a branch name. This situation is called a detached HEAD.
The HEAD can be further described as:
With the git log command the version history of a repository can be explored.
By default the command prints the following informations about each commit:
To reduce the number of logged commits to the last five for example, the log command must be executed as follows:
git log -5
With the option --oneline log prints a shorten commit-ID and the first line of the commit message only.

section.title: Limiting the number of logs
section.text: The are several options to limit the output of log to a given range of time. The command:
git log --since="3 days ago" -- DbGateways/
limits the output to the commits regarding the files within the directory DbGateways/ made the last 3 days ago.

section.title: Information about objects with show
section.text: The command show prints information about one or more objects (blobs, trees, tags and commits).
To print the contents of a file(blob) named: file1.txt from a specific commit with the shorten ID:93fd9f9802 execute:/

The git diff command can be used to show you the difference between the version of a file in the working directory, staging area (index) and most recent commit. The three main types of git diff commands you would likely use are:
git diff: Show differences between your working directory and the staging area.
git diff –cached: Show differences between the staging area and the most recent commit.
git diff HEAD: Show the differences between your working directory and the most recent commit.
At any stage, you may want to undo something. To overwrite the modified content of a file in the working tree with the content stored in the staging area use:
git checkout -- <paths>
where <paths> is the name of one or more files or directories. Be careful, because you can’t revert the modifications.
To throw away a modified file stored in the staging area use:
git reset commit-ID -- <paths>
This command stores the files (Blob's) referred by commit-ID into the staging area.
The HEAD is not touched if git checkout is executed with a <paths> separated by -- from the other options.
If you use vimdiff to compare two versions of a file and transfer the content from one to another keep the following commands / shortcuts in mind:
git difftool -t vimdiff -- file1.txt ( Vim is started by git, comparing the content of file1.txt in the working tree with the version stored in the staging are. )
:set wrap linebreak nolist ( enables soft line breaks in the current window )
]c ( jump to the next change )
[c ( jump to the previous change )
do ( get changes from other window into the current window )
dp ( put the changes from current window into the other window )
Ctrl w + w ( switch to the other window )
